newsitem.title: USA: U.S. probes Mexico job bias against pregnant women.
newsitem.headline: U.S. probes Mexico job bias against pregnant women.

text.p: The U.S. Labor Department said on Tuesday it would investigate charges that Mexico does not enforce labor laws banning job discrimination against pregnant women.
Complaints raised by three human rights groups focus on the so-called maquiladora sector, in which companies in Mexico assemble goods for export to the U.S. market.
The department will probe the allegations under the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), a pact signed by the United States, Mexico and Canada.

"The allegations in this submission are of great concern," Andrew Samet, a top Labor Department official, said in a statement. "We will use the mechanism provided in the NAFTA labor side agreement to review them, and we will report the findings to the public."

Before signing NAFTA, U.S. President Bill Clinton insisted on labor and environmental side-agreements. NAFTA opponents claimed Mexico's lower labor and environmental standards would be exploited by firms looking to cut costs.

The human rights groups claim maquiladora employers require female job applicants to verify their pregnancy status as a condition of employment and refuse to hire pregnant women, the Labor Department said.
They also allege that maquiladora employers mistreat or fire pregnant workers.
